chapter.title: Physical Environment
chapter.para: The physical environment (climate, landscape, resources) shapes cultural practices, such as food, clothing, and housing.

section.title: Geography
section.para: The geography is filled with rugged hills and valleys. It is bounded on the western boundary by a sheer mountain range with a few passes through to the vallys to the west. There are morraines, high ridges formed from glacial debris especially in the northernn areas of Merova. The southern islands expecially are composed of that kind of morraines. Many of those morraines have ridges cut out by meltwater streams often framed by large boulders at the base. There is a significant number of valleys filled with rivers, lakes and ponds.
Glacial till (a mix of sand, clay, gravel, and rocks) left behind poor, rocky soil in much of the region, though river valleys often have fertile floodplains.

The southern and eastern border are edged in rocky coastline with peninsulas, islands, and estuaries. As glaciers melted, sea levels rose, flooding coastal areas and creating features like bays and islands. There are two large bays in the region, Meara Harbor, and Badger Bay (Narragensat). Merova is easily accessed via small boats throughout the coast.

There are a set of east to west and north to south roads of solid construction. The largest is the King's Road which is a 16m wide road that runs from Meara Harbor in the east to the Great Doors in the westward pass. The roads are built with layered construction. The King's Road has 1-2m high walls on each edge. Periodically there is a Trivium, a widened plaza with some combination of stone benches, walled stalls, and fountains. Often the road rises up on elevated structures consisting of a series of arches, spans, or piers designed to carry a road over a valley, lowland, or other obstacles like rivers and wetlands.

The roads are built with a slight arch or camber to allow water to run off into ditches on either side, preventing flooding and erosion. Deep side ditches collect and direct rainwater away from the road with culverts and drainage pipes were built under the road when needed.
The roads enable a very high rate of individual and cargo travel.

section.title: Climate
section.para: The climate is characterized by four distinct seasons, including cold winters, warm summers, and moderate precipitation throughout the year. The region’s climate is influenced by its latitude, proximity to the Ocean, and varying topography.

formalpara.title: Winter
formalpara.para: Winters are cold and dry inland but moderated along the coast by the Ocean. Averages range from 10°F to 30°F (-12°C to -1°C) in the north and 20°F to 40°F (-6°C to 4°C) in southern coastal areas. Subzero temperatures are common in the northern regions, especially at night. Heavy snowfalls are typical, with annual snow accumulations of 60–100 inches (1.5–2.5 meters) in the northern and mountainous areas. Coastal areas receive less snow but can experience intense nor’easters (winter storms bringing snow, wind, and coastal flooding).

formalpara.title: Spring
formalpara.para: Gradual warming, with highs ranging from 40°F (4°C) in March to 70°F (21°C) in May. Rainfall increases, and melting snow can lead to flooding in some areas. Spring is often unpredictable, with a mix of snow, rain, and warm, sunny days. Budding trees and blooming flowers mark the season.

formalpara.title: Summer
formalpara.para: (June to August). Daytime highs average 75°F to 85°F (24°C to 29°C) across the region, with cooler temperatures in the mountains and along the coast. Heatwaves can push temperatures above 90°F (32°C), especially inland. Summers are humid, especially in southern Merova. Frequent thunderstorms, particularly in the late afternoon and evening. Summers are warm and humid, with plenty of sunny days for outdoor activities.

formalpara.title: Autumn
formalpara.para: (September to November). Crisp, cool weather with clear skies makes autumn one of the most popular seasons in Merova Cooling from 70°F (21°C) in September to 40°F (4°C) by November. Has vibrant fall foliage, with trees displaying brilliant shades of red, orange, and yellow.

formalpara.title: Rivers and Streams
formalpara.para: Abundant rivers are used for transportation, trade, and as sources of fresh water. Fast-flowing rivers power water mills for grinding grain and sawing lumber.

formalpara.title: Coastal Waters
formalpara.para: The ocean provides opportunities for near shore fishing, some deep sea fishing, and trade. Bays and harbors, like Meara Harbor, supported shipbuilding and commercial activity. Merova's waters, particularly the Grand Banks, are rich in cod, which are a cornerstone of the economy. Lobsters, clams, and oysters are also significant food and trade sources.

formalpara.title: Soil and Agriculture
formalpara.para: The soil is rocky and less fertile compared to the southern polities, making large-scale farming difficult.

formalpara.title: Granite and Slate
formalpara.para: Abundant, used for building foundations, mills, and gravestones..

formalpara.title: Iron Ore
formalpara.para: Found in bogs and streams, iron is smelted for tools, nails, and household items.

section.title: Wild Trees
section.para: Heavily forested, with a mix of coniferous and deciduous trees. The types of trees varied based on the region's soil, climate, and elevation. Below are some of the most common trees found in Merova.

formalpara.title: White Pine
formalpara.para: A tall, straight tree growing up to 200 feet, with soft, lightweight wood. Highly valued for ship masts as well as Timber for construction, furniture, and export. Resin used for making pitch and tar.

formalpara.title: Spruce
formalpara.para: Medium-sized evergreen trees with dense, needle-like foliage. Timber for building and ship planking. Resin for pitch and tar. Native Borne Spruce beer made from its needles

formalpara.title: Hemlock
formalpara.para: A shade-tolerant evergreen tree with soft needles and scaly bark. Bark used for tanning leather (high tannin content). Wood for framing and fuel

formalpara.title: Fir
formalpara.para: A fragrant evergreen with short, soft needles. Firewood and basic construction. Resin used for medicinal purposes and sealing.

formalpara.title: Oak
formalpara.para: A strong, durable hardwood tree with many species, such as white oak and red oak. Shipbuilding (hulls, keels, and frames). Furniture, tools, barrels (cooperage), and construction. Firewood, as it burns long and hot.

formalpara.title: Maple
formalpara.para: A medium-sized tree known for its striking autumn foliage and sweet sap. Sap for making maple syrup and sugar. Wood for furniture, tools, and flooring.

formalpara.title: Birch
formalpara.para: A fast-growing hardwood tree with white, yellow, or gray bark. Wood for furniture, tools, and firewood. Bark used by Native Americans for canoes and containers.

formalpara.title: Beech
formalpara.para: A large, smooth-barked hardwood tree. Durable wood for furniture and tools. Nuts provided food for wildlife and humans.

formalpara.title: Chestnut
formalpara.para: A tall hardwood tree producing edible nuts. Timber for building, as it was resistant to rot. Nuts were a significant food source for colonists and livestock.

formalpara.title: Elm
formalpara.para: A tall, graceful tree with a spreading canopy. Wood for wheel hubs, furniture, and construction. Popular for shade and ornamental purposes in colonial towns.

formalpara.title: Ash
formalpara.para: A tall, straight tree with strong, flexible wood. Handles for tools, baseball bats, and other items requiring durability. Construction and firewood.

formalpara.title: Hickory
formalpara.para: Valued for its strong wood and as fuel for high-heat fires.

formalpara.title: Willow
formalpara.para: Found along rivers and wetlands, used for baskets and medicinal purposes.

formalpara.title: Poplar
formalpara.para: Used for light construction and firewood

formalpara.title: Black Walnut
formalpara.para: They are found primarily in southernMerova, though less commonly in the northern parts of the region due to colder temperatures. Produces edible nuts enclosed in a green husk. Eaten by colonists and used as a food source, though extracting the meat from the tough shells was labor-intensive. Highly prized for its rich, dark color, black walnut wood was used for furniture, cabinetry, and gunstocks. The husks of the nuts were used to produce a dark brown dye.

formalpara.title: Butternut (White Walnut)
formalpara.para: More common than black walnut in northern parts of Merova, as it is better adapted to colder climates. Wood: Used for furniture, paneling, and small crafts, though it was softer and less durable than black walnut. Nuts: Butternut nuts were sweeter and easier to process than black walnuts, making them a popular food source. Dye: The husks were used to create a yellowish-brown dye.

formalpara.title: Apple
formalpara.para: Apples were grown for eating, cooking, and fermenting into cider (a staple beverage). Seeds and saplings were brought by Merova settlers and quickly became a staple of agriculture.

formalpara.title: Pear
formalpara.para: Cultivated for eating and cooking, though less popular than apples. Hardy and adaptable to Merova's climate

formalpara.title: Cherry
formalpara.para: Valued for their fruit and ornamental appeal.Sweet cherries and sour cherries were both introduced by Merovan settlers

chapter.title: History
chapter.para: A culture’s history, including colonization, wars, migrations, and revolutions, impacts its identity and traditions..

chapter.title: Beliefs and Values
chapter.para: The foundational principles and ideas that a culture holds to be true or important. Examples: Concepts of morality, spirituality, freedom, equality, or honor.

chapter.title: Language and Communication
chapter.para: The primary means of communication, including spoken and written languages, dialects, and non-verbal cues (gestures, body language, etc.). Language often reflects cultural priorities (e.g., Inuit languages have multiple words for snow).

chapter.title: Customs and Traditions
chapter.para: Rituals, ceremonies, and practices passed down through generations. Examples: Religious ceremonies, holidays, marriage customs, and rites of passage

chapter.title: Social Norms and Behaviors
chapter.para: Unwritten rules that govern acceptable behavior in a society. Examples: Greetings, table manners, dress codes, and etiquette.

chapter.title: Art and Aesthetics
chapter.para: Forms of creative expression, including art, music, literature, dance, and architecture. Reflects the culture's sense of beauty, symbolism, and storytelling.

chapter.title: Religion and Spirituality
chapter.para: Beliefs about the divine, the sacred, and humanity’s place in the universe. Includes organized religions and informal spiritual practices.

chapter.title: Food and Cuisine
chapter.para: The types of food a culture prepares, how it is cooked, and its significance in social or ceremonial contexts. Example: Mediterranean cultures are known for olive oil and seafood, while Japanese cuisine emphasizes rice and fish.

chapter.title: Social Organization
chapter.para: How a culture structures relationships and roles in society. Includes family dynamics, gender roles, class systems, and community hierarchies

chapter.title: Technology and Material Culture
chapter.para: Tools, technology, and objects a culture creates and uses. Example: Clothing styles, architecture, transportation, and tools reflect cultural adaptation to the environment.

chapter.title: Economics and Trade
chapter.para: How resources are produced, distributed, and consumed. Examples: Subsistence farming, industrial economies, or global trade networks.
